Ambition, power, passion - plus Beyonce, Jamie Foxx and the extraordinary, Jennifer Hudson, who can belt out a song with so much soul, that it is likely to pierce your heart...
Pretty fun in spite of itself.
Despite forgettable songs, I'm much more impressed by Dreamgirls than I am by the darling of the new musicals, Rob Marshall's Chicago.
Great performances, great singers, weak music. A mere shadow of Motown's greatest hits.
One can wish for a better, truer, more soulful version of the Motown saga. Or one can grab a seat and be dazzled.
Aside from Jennifer Hudson's beefy performance, this black r&b musical never conveys much soul.
I'll see you on the dark side of the moon...and your little dog, too!
[Condon] is one of those rare directors who can make theatricality work on film. Rather than stifling it, he embraces it, and the result is sheer exhilaration.
... a bowdlerized version of the original stage play
A poorly written film with poorly written songs and almost no character development.

It reserves singing and dancing for the stage until Jamie Foxx just randomly bursts into verse while strolling down the street. Dreamgirls wants to be Effie but ends up as Deena: thin, smooth, unburdened by a personality.
John Carney's direction is unassuming and without a hint of pretension, and his short screenplay lets the music do a lot of the talking.
This touching Irish re-imagining of the classic backstage musical has a filmmaker's eye and a poet's heart.
Whatever boldness Condon brings to the project is ultimately sunk by its disappointing lack of human drama in favor of by-the-numbers rise-and-fall theatrics.

One of the year's best films: This tragi-comic musical is Luhrmann's most audaciously innovative feature, one that creates its own hightened world, aggressively defying historical authenticity and the established conventions of Hollywood musicals.
Marvellous musical entertainment packed with performances to relish and enjoy. Wonderful stuff.
Ardent, accomplished, overwhelmingly emotional, with something to say and a dream cast saying it in song. Bravo.

The songs themselves aren't memorable so it helps greatly that they're delivered with gusto. Condon tries to pack too much in, however, and energy flags slightly towards the end. Ultimately it's Hudson's passion that keeps the dream alive.
An old-school crowd-pleaser in the best Hollywood tradition, Dreamgirls is only let down by its piecemeal structure and nominal leading lady.
Wonderful and winning Irish musical.
Pic's charm seems so offhand one might not notice the skill with which helmer John Carney pulls it off, or how it plays like a full-blown musical without anyone bursting into song.
Any movie that inspires an audience to clap during and after with such incredible performances is definitely worth your money.
It's a smiling, hopeful film, simply constructed and very emotionally appealing.

The music is glorious, but as a movie, this is a photographed play, a nostalgic evocation of small-town American that was congruent with Kennedy's New Frontier; within a year, though, Kennedy would be assassinated and the optimistic mood would vanish
Entertaining, impressively directed musical drama with a show-stopping, Oscar-nominated performance by Jennifer Hudson.
Eddie Murphy is worth the price of admission alone. He isn't so much a masculine stage presence as a walking erection with a quiff.
a mildly engrossing lecture on the pitfalls of fame -- drug abuse, failed marriages and egos run rampant -- all set to the melismatic bellowing of semi-catchy show tunes.
The opening rump-shaking immediately sets the tone: Dreamgirls pulses with sheer exuberance. When was the last time a musical, much less a huge Hollywood production, felt this alive?

There is no single person or story to centre the drama around, and Murphy's performance, though widely liked and indeed now Oscar-nominated, is for my money flatly written with very little of the high comedy octane of which we know he is capable.
This 3D remastering of the original, on a giant Imax screen to boot, brings a whole new sense of wonder to Dorothy's yellow-brick road movie.

Few pictures can match the glamorous pull of Dreamgirls. Bill Condon's first big musical since Chicago is a glossy, gleaming Cadillac of a film with a vintage rhythm and blues engine tuned to perfection. The cast is dressed to kill.
This Oscar-laden movie rendition, directed by Rob Marshall, suffers from the kind of ants-in-your-pants MTV editing that prevents you from simply watching and enjoying the musical numbers.
A shallow work without a true moral framework, it sees the world as a posturing showbusiness arena, a stage for celebrities to briefly strut their stuff and go on their way.
A stellar cast, stunning sets and costumes and engaging music make this a modern musical for a new generation.
The wit is too weak to sustain a film, and the songs all sound the same.
Decent 1961 adaptation of the Bernstein-Robbins musical, if you can handle Richard Beymer and Natalie Wood in the leads.
Woefully miscast in places and extremely dubious in its portrayal of African-Americans but does boast an on-form Dorothy Dandridge.
...less compelling than the actual history of the Supremes. Similarly, the music felt like faxed-over Motown, a couple of generations less crisp than the original.
The best reason to revisit Carmen Jones lies in Dorothy Dandridge's electrifying performance, which saw her become the first African-American to be nominated for a Best Actress Oscar.

Every frame, you feel, is freighted with the tension imposed by the never-appearing white folks. It was, however, laudable in its desire to showcase the talents of African-American performers who were denied opportunities in Hollywood.

To say that Dreamgirls is the best musical so far this century is to make no great claim for it. To say that it's the best film about the music business since 1996's Grace of My Heart and fit to be spoken of in the same breath says more.
I could have happily sat through the first half a second time, though I was barely able to sit through the second half once.

Jennifer Hudson makes her acting debut in Bill Condon's Dreamgirls, and it's safe to say the phrase "star-making turn" was invented for performances like hers.
Newcomer Jennifer Hudson owns the movie with her magnetic presence and go-tell-it-on-the-mountain voice.* ** ** *
Tsai's emptied-out aesthetic has never felt so empty, his mannerisms so pointlessly mannered.
Tsai uses the vernacular of pornography against itself: every image is empty, obvious, posed.
Straddles that fine line between Chinese art film and Asian porn.
The Taiwanese sex musical The Way ward Cloud is notable for its bizarre uses of watermelons. I won't give you the details because my editor would just cut them out.
The Wayward Cloud offers one plausible moral: If life hands you watermelons, make love to them.
One of Hollywood's best musicals.
Una lujosa produccin que, a nivel dramtico, tiene la misma profundidad que una telenovela. Eso s: hay (alguna) buena msica y una inusual actuacin de Eddie Murphy.
A chronicle of colonialism that poses itself as an easy-to-dismiss artifact, yet reveals itself to be an enduring statement about why people can't get along.

Self-reflexive, narcissistic, and entertaining, this film is Fosse's 81/2 (he even uses Fellini's cinemtographer Rotunno). High production values and superb acting by Roy Scheider as the artist's alter-ego makes this morbid musical Fosse's best work.
There's a lot of cool stuff on display here, but it lacks the consistent creative vision--or, if you like, the pure imagination--of the original film.
There's no faint-praise here. It's the best film of the year.
God, The Sound of Music is so freakin' nice.
Dreamgirls is a splashy film with a great cast, strong performances, terrific music and an engrossing, though...familiar, story.
Once is the David Gray or James Blunt of movie musicals, and amazingly enough, that's not a bad thing.
You may not be expecting this from a musical, but Dreamgirls is one of the most fast-paced, frenetically-edited, roller-coaster rides of a movie that you'll see all year.
Few recent American musicals are this fluid or engaging.
A lavish musical, too lavish for the subject matter, though.

Possibly the first Hollywood movie to design a fairy tale of sorts around globalization, the film conjures a mythic Brit multinational instead of the usual imperial realm, asa basically high caloric magical kingdom.
Mr. Luhrmann and his colleagues have worked like whirling dervishes to make the plot look like it's moving.
A charming and endearing Irish film about two down-and-out individuals who collaborate on a musical project that deeply enriches them both in surprising ways.
Too talky.
ONCE isn't a perfect film, it begins a little wobbly but once its leading lady makes her entrance, the movie soars and turns into a haunting love story that is set to gorgeous music.
Once is twice-blessed: good songs, and a real story--not just a clothesline on which the tunes can hang.
It deserves to be seen and offers more real human emotion than most of the year's would be box office busters.
The magic of the movie is how utterly wrenching it renders [its] songs, which thrive alongside the film's simple, eloquent, dusky narrative.
...a unique twist on the musical with this affecting story of unrequited love between a couple who express their emotions through their song lyrics.
The emo-oriented, folksy score may be the most memorable original film music in some time.
Once makes a persuasive case that the real future of the movie musical may lie not in splashy grandeur but in modesty and understatement.
The movie swoons, and you will too.
No matter what your musical tastes, Once will reinforce your belief in the power of melody and harmony to heal one's inner wounds.
Once may not boast stellar production values or elaborate dance numbers, but in its own scruffy way it captures the spirit of the genre better than any recent Hollywood musical.
Focusing strictly on stripped-down performances of great music and the charming chemistry between the two leads, it's a perfectly realized yet unassuming movie that deserves to find a big audience.
So heartfelt and sparse, so quietly genuine with its dingy digital images -- so not Rent.

Once is one of those urban fairy tales you come out of not wanting to switch on your car radio, make small talk or do anything but shelter in its beguiling ambiance for as long as you can to avoid re-entering the real world.
Everything about Once feels unforced and natural.
I adored it, fell madly in love with each frame each note each nuance each lyric.
The film drags a bit and Irglova's inexperience as an actor sometimes leaves her costars in the lurch. But it's a sweet little film just the same.
Cut through the Spidey-Shrek hype and seek it out. You won't be sorry. It's a magical, beguiling wonder.
Imagine Belle And Sebastian remaking In The Mood For Love as a heartbreaking low-fi musical, and you have a fair approximation of the film's melancholy, unexpected genius.
Couldn't be less bogus if James Blunt sat on a stage in front of an empty bar saying "this one's for the lady in the back."
A lively and brash musical comedy spectacle.
The perfect movie to fall in love with, as well as the perfect movie to fall in love to.
Once is a winning and engaging portrait of two people's powerful connection through music.
It takes all of 10 seconds for John Carney's Once to announce itself as something special.
Forget the generic title, Once is an utterly beguiling, pitch perfect romantic musical that speaks volumes about love, passion, creativity, and hope.
Once isn't especially complex, but the chemistry between its appealing leads feels deeply true. You'd have to look awfully hard to find such sincerity in a Hollywood romance.
That musical chemistry also plays out nicely onscreen, because you believe they're really into each other.
Worse than a movie of the weak (pun intended)
Pragmatically recognizing life's hardships while romantically yearning for something more gives Once a quintessentially Irish flavor, as well as a poignancy that's both hard-edged and heartfelt.
Somehow the world just seems to be a better place once you've seen Once.
I guarantee to you that this film will, in a few years, be regarded as a small classic. Discover Once now.
A musical for people who HATE musicals.
Amazing music, great performances. This is really, truly a musical, in the best sense of the word.
{Glen] Hassard and {Marketa] Irglova, newcomers to feature film, show both natural acting skills and terrific musical ability.
Wins you over without appearing even to try... Once...is so emotionally resonant and exuberantly enjoyable that you might just want to see it more than that.
Once is the genuine article: a winning love story told with simple grace and humanity.

As great as Once's songs will be on the soundtrack, it cannot compare to the visual stimuli that accompanies the long notes Hansard cries out and the backup that Iglova compliments like a guardian angel.
For reasons they'll have to go to hell for someday, the Motion Picture Association of America ratings board gave Once an R, for a handful of swear words. Ignore that. And enjoy the film.
May appeal especially to romantic young people who can develop crushes on the lead characters in tandem with the smittenness that emerges onscreen.
It's a musical courtship--he on guitar, her on piano, and both in vocal harmony. It's also a scruffy cinematic sleeper with which anyone's liable to fall in love.
very natural and believable character study of two people attracted through music
In its brief running time, writer-director John Carney does something both profound and unexpected: He reinvents the movie musical as a genre of swooning rock 'n' roll realism.

The songs don't advance the narrative lyrically so much as follow the two characters' uncertain relationship through the slow realization of their themes; in particular a scene in which they first jam together in the back room of a music store is a gem.
[A] wonderful film that is one of the year's best.

Once is a love story told in songs, a romance between two people just getting to know each other, and the music is completely organic to both their tentative attraction and their backstories as individuals.
The most naturalistic and believable romantic musical you may ever see and hear.
A sweet, raw blessing of a film.
Sweet but never cloying, simple without being simplistic, delicate yet not at all precious, this is a film guaranteed to set your toes to tapping even as it plays a number on your heartstrings.
This is an unusual and completely engaging movie.
Elegantly capturing the alchemy of songwriting -- not to mention the alchemy of fleeting romance -- it's a one-of-a-kind movie to enthrall musicians and listeners alike.
Once proves once and for all that imagination trumps big bucks.

This indie musical is a bijou of a film that joins unaffected performances and a compelling soundtrack in a low-budget, documentary-style film that lets us watch two people fall in love to the mesmerizing soundtrack of the songs they create.
Even the uninitiated will be hard-pressed to resist the movie's charms, from its likable leading players and its charming Dublin setting to its wistful take on modern love.
...music that struggles to achieve mediocrity and a bland story.

Stripped of just about all artifice and dazzle, shot on the cheap on city streets, this Sundance gem is wiser about artistic creation and the fickle ways of love than any song-and-dance spectacular you've recently encountered.
As a story about people with songs coursing through their veins--Julie Andrews notwithstanding--Once captures the true Sound of Music.
The perfect movie for people who love music.
A television director and two musicians have made a miracle of a movie that is both fairy tale and slice of life.
Once transcends even its own ambitions, becoming a complex meditation on relationships, Irish culture, and music.
One of the movie's pleasures is that it keeps us asking what sort of love story will Once become?
Once, a film so sweet, unassuming, real, surefooted and warm that you might find yourself loving it as you would a person, is a bare-bones boy-meets-girl story.
Part of the fun of watching Once is that it's unlike other musicals, other movies.
Once contains more magic than most other musicals.

Musicals ask us to take a happy leap of faith, to believe in a world in which people express their feelings by bursting into song. With Once, Carney has created that world within our own, and it weaves an irresistible spell.
One of the all-time great film musicals with dazzling Streisand.
Definitely worth the bucks. Take your honey to this for a date. You'll be glad you did.
Hansard and Irglov (who have worked together musically) are convincing in this slight not-quite-romantic fantasy that does nothing more than affirm the possibility of human connection, however brief.

Given [director] Carney's roughshod methods, Once never resembles a standard studio offering, which works much to its benefit. Between Carney's unadorned writing and his rustic directing approach, Once always remains grounded in reality.
It somehow manages to pay homage to the old Hollywood musicals as it reinvents them. It's a film that's rooted in the real world yet also manages to transcend it.
A top viewing choice for the musically-inclined cynical idealist.
It's the answer to our cinematic prayers, not just for a believable musical, but also a terrific movie in general.
Music video masquerades as a heart-on-sleeve narrative featuring a charismatic, if musically limited and redundant, Glen Hansard of the Irish rock band the Frames.

Told with the simplicity of a Chaplin film (more than once I was reminded of City Lights), Once has the tentative and unpredictable amble of a chance encounter rather than the absolute and overdetermined structure of a Hollywood film.
The best musical of a generation? No, but it is good.
A portrait of an intimate musical friendship that becomes a safe harbor for two ships passing in the night.

Are you looking for a little film you can make your own, an enchanting, unpretentious blend of music and romance you can watch forever? If you do, Once is about to come into your life and make it whole.
Once owes its genuine immediacy to the blessed decision to capture its musicians in the flush of actual performance.
Thanks to the ingratiating lead performers and their honest music performances, and the sensitivities of writer-director John Carney, it's a story worth seeing.
Unforgettable melody is the foundation of this heartfelt Irish romance that puts a twist on the movie musical.
Communicates the world of the singer-songwriter brilliantly. That said, as a complete film on its own -- Once could be more fulfilling.
A real masterpiece of puppetry and special effects, an absolutely gorgeous children's fantasy movie.
A romantic fairy tale of astonishing delicacy and emotional nuance. This movie is so good I wasn't even bothered by [director] Carney never giving his characters names.
I can't imagine anyone seeing Once and not instantly falling in love with it.
There's not a false moment within the film's 88-minute running time, nor many that could be done any better.
Astonishing...it cleaves through the conventions of the musical form, leaving the raw emotion but junking the showy glitz.
Sweet and surprisingly involving, and several of the songs deserve to be hits.
The fact that the music seems to come from an organic source, growing out of the characters and intertwined with the story, makes Once a singularly touching musical.

The real dialogue is the music, as the lovers communicate through lyrics. The filmmaking is unadorned, but the emotional virtuosity is rhapsodic.
One of the best of the Astaire-Rogers musicals, and one that shouldn't have worked as well as it did.

Another winner for the Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers combo. It's smart, modern, and impressive in every respect, from its boy-loses-girl background to its tunefulness, dancipation, production quality and general high standards.
A fancy package of musical entertainment with wide appeal and bright grossing prospects.
One of the shining glories of the American musical.
I don't find the film light or joyful in the least -- an air of primal menace hangs about it, which may be why I love it.
Never was a director more aptly named than Sam Wood: his movies are redwood forests of unrelieved monotony.

Fondly remembered for such classic comedy bits as Groucho and Chico drafting a contract, the stateroom scene, and the hilarious climax where the brothers make a shambles of Il Trovatore. Sans Duck Soup, we'll watch this any day.
The backstage finish, with Harpo doing a Tarzan on the fly ropes, contains more action than the Marxes usually go in for, but it relieves the strictly verbal comedy and provides a sock exit.
Whatever this 1972 feature is, it's entertaining and stylish, though maybe not quite as serious as it wants to be.
The screenplay, which never seems to talk down to an audience while at the same time making its candid points with tasteful emphasis, returns the story to a variety of settings.
Don't miss Once. It has to be seen and heard to be believed and enjoyed.

The chemistry between Hansard and Irglov flows from the screen, easily creating one of the most romantic films of our generation. Independently redefining this classic genre, Once is a musical that movingly tells a realistic love story.

This lovely tale of a love affair between a Dublin street musician and a flower girl will leave you wistful for more. It's a movie to fall in love with and a movie to fall in love during. It is the most naturalistic musical ever.
It has a Before Sunrise vibe, but the aphrodisiac is music rather than pseudo-philosophical Gen-X ramblings.
Once captures the intoxicating one-two punch of loving music and falling in love better than any movie since Tender Mercies and The Buddy Holly Story (1978).
Henson's imagination is boundless. But his movie has no pep. It's a dream in neutral.

John Travolta takes on John Waters in Hairspray, and the result is anything but a drag in this appealingly goofy, all-singing, all-dancing screen adaptation of the Broadway musical based on the 1988 film.

It's one of the best Broadway-tuner adaptations in recent years -- yes, arguably even better than those Oscar-winning ones. Unpretentious, feel-good pic is low on histrionic diva wailing and MTV-style editing, high on retro movie-musical craftsmanship.

A much-needed respite from summer's big, noisy, special effects adventures, Hairspray is old-fashioned fun, wearing its retro like a badge of honor; the "coolest" thing about this uplifting musical is how mainstream it is.
Here is magic-realism filtered through an oddball sensibility, chilled in the snowdrifts of Winnipeg and bottled in amber-hued frames of celluloid.

Carney becomes a little too enamored of the cinematographic limitations, and loses some important scenes to darkness and lousy focus. Call me crazy, but I like to actually see cinematic moments of emotional longing and heartache, not try to squint them in
Quietly and modestly inches its way into your heart, and by the time it reaches its wrenching and beautiful closing scene, you know you've experienced something special.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: It's a different kind of movie than your typical summer fare, but it never hits a wrong note and art-house lovers should see it... at least once.

A wonderfully touching but thoroughly offbeat romance, interlaced with songs.
A terrific, good looking, beautifully acted ride and a perfect summer change of pace

One of the most exciting pieces of filmmaking to hit theaters in a long time.

A fast-paced, hugely-entertaining romp that'll have you dancing all the way home.

Adam Shankman's movie of the Broadway Hairspray gets better as it lumbers along, but there's something garish about its hustle -- it's like an elephant trumpeting in your face.
Hairspray is perfectly pleasant -- I smiled to myself all the way through it -- but it's not as exhilarating as the show.
All of that is just done so well, and you just love the spirit of this.
Hairspray proves that summer movie fun needn't be witless and/or soulless.
This bright, bouncy movie musical is a happy surprise, a candy-colored ode to outsiders that left me with a big grin.
Hairspray exceeded my expectations and, while it isn't my favorite movie of the pool-and-beach season, it's enjoyable enough to earn a recommendation.
Offering plenty of body and a lot of lift, Hairspray gels kitsch styling with show-stopping tunes to mould a memorable musical.
Though not as scabrous, as sharp or even as musically memorable as John Waters' original, it retains much of his filthy, big-hearted sensibility.
It's a toe-tapper to make your forget sashaying pirates, comic-book heroes, robot Camaros and cartoons. This is the movie event of the summer.
No winking, no mugging -- just earnest, wholesome, knock-your-socks-off fun.
A rousing alternative in a marketplace packed with noisy, special-effects-heavy sequels, Hairspray is the best and most entertaining movie adaptation of a stage musical so far this century.
An odd hybrid that lacks both the rambunctious energy of a live performance and the expressionistic pull of a great movie musical.
A touching, tender and smart film that effectively blends elements of musical and romance, while maintaining an air of realism and honesty one rarely finds in either genre.
Three cheers for this jubilant, funny, and phantasmagorical musical!
Energetic, funny and entertaining; there's nothing stiff about Hairspray
Takes the attitude of the original to a giddy new level.
It's all about the music, baby. And the rollicking tunes and flashy dance numbers carry the day. This new "Hairspray" is as good as it could possibly be.

Based on John Waters' 1988 satire of civil rights-era nostalgia, this movie-musical adaptation makes the same mistake as the 2002 Broadway incarnation -- it domesticates Waters' parodistic anarchy into general-audience silliness.
Hairspray is a fizzy and delirious high-camp message-movie musical that may just turn out to be the happiest movie of the summer.
One of the best movie musicals in recent times and it only gets better on repeated viewings.
If ever there were a happy summer movie, it's Hairspray.

Hairspray is the perfect example of cinematic synchronicity -- flawless casting, amazing material, brilliant production design, stellar songs and directorial magic all rolled up into one big wad of motion picture cotton candy
More a reinvention than a retread, Hairspray is a pleasant surprise, a breath of fresh, whimsical air in a season that's been dominated by franchise entertainment.
When Hairspray slows or stumbles, which it often does, the direction and choreography (both by Adam Shankman) pull it back together fast, and it keeps on trucking.
Limp, cheaply made.
Good, clean, high-spirited fun.
Grease has got it, from the outstanding animated titles of John Wilson all the way through the rousing finale as John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John ride off into teenage happiness.
It's a satire that functions the same way the stuff it's satirizing does.
By the big finale, even homophobes will tap their feet. OK, maybe not. But the less close-minded are sure to respond. Hairspray has a beat. And you sure can dance to it.

This screen-to-stage-to-screen disaster spits in the face of John Waters' decade-defining pop pastiche of harmonious camp and progressive thinking, retaining the basic plotline and anti-segregationist morals but none of the authenticity.
...singing her heart out and swinging her hips, Blonsky is oblivious to the prejudices and insecurities of the real world. Her ignorance is our bliss.
...Hairspray is a surprisingly effervescent ice cream soda of a musical, fizzing with sly comic performances and a bonanza of heel-thumping numbers.
The real star of this Hairspray is director-choreographer Adam Shankman.
A goofy bouffant of a movie primped with rich '60s atmosphere and held together by the gloss coat of Marc Shaiman's swinging music.
That Hairspray is good-hearted is no surprise. The surprise may be that this Hairspray, stuffed with shiny showstoppers, is actually good.
Still sings and swings in all the right ways.
Less focused than John Waters' subversive and satirical original, but nonetheless brings a smile to your face and is destined to get your feet tapping.
Only a die-hard grump could resist the giddy charms of Hairspray.
The film's an irresistible time capsule of that Camelot summer, blending girrrrrl power, social consciousness and faux-'60s pop with the fizz of a soda jerk whipping up a root beer float.
As mile-high-wig musicals go, the film version of Hairspray is less polished but more fun than Dreamgirls. Both are drag revues at heart, one funny, the other serious. I prefer the funny one.
Travolta's rather unfunny and sometimes tone-deaf turn in drag and a fat suit is the one sore-thumb element in what is otherwise a pretty energetic and enjoyable musical-comedy.
Bouncy and campy, a cotton-candy entertainment feast.
This movie musical about the plus-sized white girl who shakes her way onto a segregated teen dance show and brings black high-schoolers with her is a laughing gas.

The movie pulsates with so much energy and excitement that it sometimes seems it will come bouncing off the screen. But then someone applies another layer of lacquer to their 'do, and the whole boisterous bouffant of a show somehow sticks together.
Hairspray more than fulfills that most basic (but not easy) task of the movie musical: It leaves audiences frugging their way down the aisle.
I can't recall a movie with this many flaws that I liked so much.

It's a pallid, unthreatening version of Waters' original, but it's also breezy, light entertainment, good clean fun on the order of -- who'd have thought it? -- Disney's blockbuster High School Musical.
You'll come out of the movie happier than you went in, and humming a few peppy new tunes to boot.
With its wisecracking screenplay, period-perfect pop score, and Shankman's splashy choreography, this may be the funniest, dancingest screen musical since Singin' in the Rain.
Several beautifully intercut musical numbers keep the action moving and the dialogue in between is sweet, tart and subversive.
Hairspray is a feel-good musical that, for a change, actually makes you feel good.
Traditionally, movie musicals are released in the 'serious' fall season. But the shamelessly exuberant Hairspray is a summer film and proud of it.
What it offers isn't really a nostalgic look at a 'more innocent time' so much as a saucy wink at a casually vicious time that is constantly being sold to us as innocent.

The jokes rarely miss and the result is a refreshingly sardonic fairy tale.
Adams is truly magical. She brews up her most transfixing expressions when words fail her.
The sight of Adams gliding and beaming and chirping in this movie is just about the happiest time I've had watching an actor do anything all year.
A heart-winning musical comedy that skips lightly and sprightly from the lily pads of hope to the manhole covers of actuality, if you see what I mean. I'm not sure I do.
Enchanted manages the trick of recasting sugar spun Disney fairy tales of old into a winning, modern-day comedy. Walt Disney would be impressed.
A gently meta fairy tale that pokes fun at Disney's animated classics, just never too hard to hurt.

It's novel, it's amusing and it can't help but peter out in the third act as the screenplay trucks toward a Big Apple showdown between good and evil. By this time, Enchanted is merely coasting on Adams' considerable charm. It's enough.
There's plenty to enjoy here.
Disney satirizes its own princess megabusiness -- but still goes for the standard payoffs -- with this funny story of a fairy-tale heroine who finds herself in real-life New York City.
It's obvious but inescapable: Enchanted is as good as its name.
The film affectionally spoofs animated-fantasy formulas.
Cute and clever enough to enchant little girls -- not to mention their mothers.
Adams' performance is the kind that deserves an Academy Award nomination yet seldom gets one.
Enchanted is worth seeing for Adams, and children will adore the slapstick performers, including a prominently featured CGI chipmunk.
The results look something like an overscaled Muppet movie (which ain't such a bad thing in itself).
Enchanted hits every high note, and a great family film that entertains both the kids and adults is something we can all be truly thankful for.
Enchanted squeaks by on the charm of its performers, particularly Adams.
An irresistible blend of screwball comedy and Disney fairy-tale musical, Enchanted takes its enchanting premise and prances away with it, holding the audience happily captive.
How refreshing it is that Enchanted gently makes fun of Disney tradition while upholding it at the same time. There are no cheap or vulgar jokes, and sentiment never turns to treacle.
Surprisingly sophisticated riff on animated fairy-tale movie cliches.
The film, anchored by an entrancing performance by Amy Adams and a strong ensemble cast, is cleverly written. The situations are funny, and the story feels effortlessly entertaining.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: Charming. I wanted to sing all the way home and make some clothes out of my favorite curtains.
Enchanted isn't just a culture-clash fable, it's also a throwback to one of classic Hollywood's giddiest genres: the screwball comedy.
Wonderful performances by Amy Adams and James Marsden as the real-life versions of a classic Disney princess and her prince charming. They are magnificent.
What could have been an epic Disney misfire is saved by the charming Adams.
Enchanted is not a perfect movie ... But it is so thoroughly delightful when Adams is on screen you forgive its faults with a smile.
An inspired Disney fairy-tale mash-up.
Portraying a version of Disney's Snow White, [Adams] owns the character, down to every warble and twirl.
Disney goes meta in this witty, exuberant musical comedy whose parody and nostalgia serve a sweet and affecting romance.
Maybe it's not a whole new world, but it's one you already know and love quite well.
If I have my druthers Adams will get her second Oscar nomination, part of me even hoping she can pull of the same Julie Andrews Mary Poppins miracle and actually win the darn golden statue outright.
The gag wouldn't work with just anyone in the lead, but Adams' openhearted performance never winks. She really does want the best for everyone, and can't fathom why they don't all feel the same.
Adams carries Enchanted's fairy-tale conceit on her tiny shoulders - and on her, it floats as if sprinkled with pixie dust.
[Adams has] got a wild-eyed spark that suggests she's probably game for just about anything. I hope Hollywood doesn't sand her down too much and turn her into a bland star.
Adams gives a great performance. Her sincerity is what makes it all work.
Wonderful family entertainment.
Adams is somehow more cartoonish than the animated version of Giselle at the beginning of the film.
Amy Adams looks and sounds as if she indeed emerges from a fairy-tale land.
I walked in there all crabby, tired, bitter, and sad, and I walked out with a beatific smile on my face that not even Beowulf could remove entirely.
What pushes the film over the top is the terrific turn by Adams, who really seems like a Disney heroine come to life.
This is a film Walt himself would have been proud of, a family flick that's marvelously gratifying no matter what your age.
The first half of this film is just pure joy.
...winsomely clever...
It makes for good family viewing.
With its buoyant combination of romance, music and fun, 'Enchanted' emerges as one of the most entertaining films of the year.
Enchanted earns its label as a "family film" by virtue of its ability to captivate audience members both young and old.
A surprisingly entertaining movie that possesses the trademark Disney magic while administering a few well-deserved jabs in the ribs at the same time.
A very nice enjoyable fluffy movie.

Sarandon's wicked queen switches it up as a witch on the down low, exuding bad vibes crackling with charismatic menace. Even if a bit like a real queen also notorious for not taking a liking in the least to her own royal offspring's choices in women.
Watching Amy Adams exude her comical charm is alone worth the price of admission.
Maintains a delicate balance between wish-fulfillment fantasy and a recognition that the world inhabited by its audience is filled with disappointment as well as with joy...
Disney's Enchanted is the sweet, lighthearted antithesis to the more serious fare this holiday season, fueled by a thoroughly captivating performance from Amy Adams.
If the mere notion of Disney returning to their roots doesn't at least bring a tiny bit of a smile to your face, then you are, I'm sorry, completely dead inside.
To my pleasure, the delightful Enchanted stands out in a season full of violent and drug-ridden movies.

Travolta as bosomy mom Edna in perky fat suit, with flab-infatuated spouse Walken never far behind, pretty much steals the show from everybody else as he impressively shakes his bountiful booty across the dance floor.
The whole thing is rather forced and antiseptically cheerful.
Bing Crosby and Danny Kaye, along with VistaVision, keep the enteratinment going in this fancifully staged production, clicking well.
Though it's not as satisfying as it might have been, it still boasts great stars and catchy songs in addition to a love story, and is a perennial holiday favorite.
With a cast like this, the ensuing light-hearted mayhem and Irving Berlin's title song, there is not much cause to complain if you're looking for nothing more than mild diversion.
This is the dullest and least successful adaptation of the Christmas chestnut I've ever seen.
A mixed bag of mixed moods.
Nothing can really diminish the late Jim Henson's irresistibly appealing characters.
The fit between sentiment and satire is not always a comfortable one and the more dedicated fans of either the story or the Muppets may leave theaters dissatisfied.
The kids and adults can dig this one, though adults may be stricken with Disney deja vu by this point.

Amy Adams does something akin to what Johnny Depp did in the first Pirates picture: take a potentially generic Disney movie and invest it with a sublimely inventive performance that takes the overall product to a whole other level.
There are probably a few actresses who could play the role of an animated Disney princess come to life, but let's be thankful it's Amy Adams who is playing it.
Enchanted offers us five-stars worth of Amy Adams in four-stars worth of movie. That's not a bad average.
Playing her fairytale character with giddy aplomb, Amy Adams gives a winsomely energetic performance as the live-action version of maiden Giselle.
The delightful Enchanted gives Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs a sweetly subversive spin.
A sweet little film for anyone that enjoys blurring the lines between fantasy and reality. Climaxes strongly. Has moments of greatness and moments of not-so-greatness.
Though colorful, cheery and energetic, there's something missing from this song-and-dance routine.
Disney can afford to poke fun at a lot of things about itself, and in Enchanted, it does exactly that, to largely charming effect.
This magical fantasy-in-reverse is perhaps the best family film of the year.
The story is so very strong. The music is so magnificent. And with undeniable performances by Depp, Rickman, and Baron Cohen, the film really works.

Dark, haunting, and visionary, Sweeney Todd reps Tim Burton's best film since Ed Wood and his most challenging teaming with Johnny Depp. A mesmerizing, Oscar-caliber work that should satisfy Sondheim's fans and bring new recruits.
It may sound like faint praise to say that Enchanted is the movie of the year for smart and spirited 11-year-old girls. But a movie that genuinely respects that audience is not to be belittled.
The dedicated fairy tale fan will have tons of fun spotting all the references. Adams, meanwhile, gives one of the comedy performances of the year.
Enchanting for most of its running time.
This represents one happy instance of a film made by a director without stage experience that genuinely serves the intentions of the original piece.
The show couldn't have fallen into better hands.
Some magical balance between the cast members, the set design, the songs and director Adam Shankman makes it work.
One's enjoyment of Adam Shankman's motion picture will largely depend on one's tolerance for conflict-less, feel good musicals.
It's bloody -- and it's bloody excellent.
Moulin Rouge took me by surprise.

This is the film everyone will be talking about - and seeing repeatedly - this summer. Clocking in at less than an hour and a half, it's a small and perfectly formed gem that will leave you glowing for days.

There were a thousand wrong turns Burton and crew could have taken, but somehow they avoided them. They condensed a complicated three-hour show into a highly entertaining two hours without missing a beat -- literally.
For the most part this is a perky delight that takes a cheeky glee in biting the gloved hand that feeds.
Once upon a time, the Disney studios showed off a clever way to blend animation and live action.
Like your high school's production of "Grease": A musical about sex with a chastity belt strapped to its waist.
The performances are pitched at just the right scale: theatrically exaggerated but untainted by "Broadway" bombast. Who knew Burton would have such an uncanny feel for how to film a musical?

Since Sweeney Todd premiered in 1979, screen serial killers have multiplied like so many disposable razors. Making the audience feel something more than the thrill of watching movie stars is the challenge here, and Sweeney Todd somehow cuts itself short.
Outstanding singing performances from its gifted ensemble cast contrast unfavorably with Burton's trademark affinity for a monochromatic color scheme of white, blue, brown and gray.
Disney's idea is to postmodernize their own princess franchises, and instead of going after them with snark, the references are giddy and gleeful (and quite numerous).
Thoroughly delightful and entertaining, this is exactly the type of movie Walt Disney would make if he were alive today.
Burton delivers a less comic, more appealing Sweeney Todd in this Johnny Depp tour-de-force. Frankly, it's bloody great.

Where previous Sweeneys have found room in the character for both anguish and exultation amidst all the faraway looks and obsessional glowering, Depp skirts along the edge of the emotional chasm without ever really diving in.
Burton has an affinity for the mayhem's Grand Guignol setting, of course. But more valuably, he has a unique collaborative relationship with his longtime leading man.
Enchanted? You will be.
It's only when the story hits the streets of NYC and Adams starts hamming it up (much like Julie Hagerty did in 'Airplane') that we start seeing the fruits of a grand Mickey-take.

Subversive enough for older brother, sweet enough for kid sis, this cine-panto's a safe if not spectacular choice for a Chrimbo family outing. The cartoon chipmunk almost steals it, but Adams' dippy dazzle is the movie's heart, soul and lungs.
A charming family-friendly film complete with a beautiful music score.
Sweeney Todd is a thriller-diller from start to finish: scary, monstrously funny and melodically thrilling. And Depp is simply stupendous.

Overrated at the time of release, the Oscar-winning Oliver! is a skillful but unexciting movie musical, one that softens considerably Dicken's famous novel, and not helped much by the mediocre staging of the production numbers.
Enchanting, fantastic fun for all the family.
It's not quite as enchanted or magical as it could have been, but this family romp still manages to be good fun, and is lifted by fantastic turns from Amy Adams and James Marsden.

Kicking off as a traditional 2-D animation before transforming into live animation when we hit the Big Apple, the film's title doesn't quite describe the film's likely effect on adults, but girls aged six-12 are sure to love it.
Susan Sarandon is terrific as the Evil Queen; Timothy Spall pops up like a well-used wart; and James Marsden is the terrifically thick and handsome Prince.

Beginning like the classic animated stories, with a beautiful princess being rescued by a handsome prince, it raises a laugh immediately with a brilliant send-up of the saccharin duets the young lovers usually sing.
Overhyped family movie covered in a cellophane shrink-wrap of corporate Disney plastic-ness.
The comic possibilities, once floated, eventually capsize.
A triumphant return to form.
It quickly becomes obvious that instead of finding a fresh angle of approach, the filmmakers have simply given us yet another fish-out-of-water fantasy a la "Splash."
The animated sequences are disappointingly flat, the real-life parts underwritten, but Amy Adams works hard and keeps a straight face in the lead, and the time passes amiably enough.
This family film is fun, but essentially paint-by-numbers.
A minimalist musical which makes the most of the 'boy-meets-girl theme.
The songs, by "Pocahontas" Oscar-winners Alan Menken and Stephen Schwartz, are cleverly written, with each one evoking a Disney classic from another period.
Carney's Once is definitely not enough...thoroughly inspirational, lyrical, charming and cheeky...a winning spark that ignites the lovelorn imagination.
Enchanted bubbles over with good cheer, due in large part to Adams for the wide-eyed optimism and innocence she brings to her irony-free performance.
It's awash in grimly gorgeous sights, mercilessly dark humor, oddly amusing tunes, and all sorts of strange goings-on ... Burton and Depp strike gothic gold once again.
This Sweeney Todd blasts audaciously away with all the forces and resources of cinematic realization in a smashing production.
How do you rescue the hell brew from absurdity?
Tim Burton's film of Stephen Sondheim's Sweeney Todd is spellbinding.
Even for Tim Burton and Johnny Depp it's really dark material.
While too closed-in and stagy to be effectively cinematic, 'Sweeney' is still an effectively blood-curdling revenge thriller and perhaps a satiric commentary on capitalism's cannibalistic thrust.
A cynical, chill-inducing, blood-splattering cinematic operetta! Forget about your preconceptions - and relish one of the 10 Best Movies of 2007.
The perfect marriage of artist and material.
This grisly, grim and ghoulish gothic tale of vengeance is a thoroughly entertaining gore-filled experience, whether you're a fan of musicals or not.
Keeping every performer on point, Burton draws the strongly structured material together to produce a black comedy and still blacker tragedy surging with jugular urgency. It haunts the mind for days.
A Grand Guignol, with plot elements from Jacobean tragedy, The Count of Monte Cristo, and Jack the Ripper, it's the perfect mlange for the master of the macabre, Tim Burton.

As much as he's a filmmaker, Burton is also a graphic artist in the tradition of Charles Addams and Edward Gorey -- and here he's successfully incorporated Sweeney Todd into his own distinctively dank and spidery gothic world.
Revenge is a dish best served cold, exactly how I was left after watching Helena Bonham Carter butcher a cheeky star turn in Tim Burton's cutthroat musical.
Tell me, is it good? Sir, it's too good at least. It's mighty entertainment that makes you feel sorry for the poor saps in the next theater at the multiplex.
Despite the weak vocal work, the film does nevertheless border on brilliance, and seems to be a shoo in for an Academy Award nomination.

Once doesn't plop its emotions on its characters' sleeves, and it trusts us enough to leave some of the best stuff unstated. In other words, it trusts us to know that half the music lies between the notes.
Everything a Burton picture should be, everything a musical should be, everything the play should be and everything the venerable horror story of good old Sweeney should be.
Sweeney Todd certainly succeeds as spectacle, but for the first time in a long time, Burton is completely keyed into the human drama unfolding in front of him.
Sweeney Todd has been my favorite stage musical for years. Now it is my favorite film of 2007.
In the end, the real problem with the Demon Barber of Fleet Street is that he's not as bloody fun as he should be.
This well-sung and perfectly acted adaptation falls way short of a triumph because Burton misplaces his sense of humor. He only almost makes Sweeney Todd his own.
You might not be humming the songs when you leave the theater, but the haunting visuals will definitely stick in your head.
The most obvious reference point for 2007 Best Picture nominee Sweeney Todd is Baz Luhrmann's equally fluid 2001 Best Picture nominee Moulin Rouge!
An invigorating experience that ranks among the best stage-to-screen translations ever filmed.
Turns out Sweeney Todd needed Tim Burton more than Tim Burton needed Sweeney Todd.
If you can handle the blood-spurting scenes Sweeney Todd might be a movie to check out after the glow of the holiday bulbs has dimmed.
You'll be twisted, manipulated and repulsed, but always entertained. You might also find yourself uttering "God, That's Good."
A striking if stomach-turning big-screen treatment.
It breathes new life into the genre by dousing it in buckets of blood.
Dismal sets, cartoonish gore and Johnny Depp singing -- what's so appealing about that? Just about everything, actually.

It's strangely beautiful and beautifully strange, with horrific subject matter that produces plenty of wicked humor and characters who initially seem ghoulish but ultimately reveal themselves as sympathetic and deeply sad.
One of the most memorable films of the year.
A cheeky, good-looking splatter fest that humorlessly shoves the grimness of Stephen Sondheim's stage musical in the viewer's face. The result: ugh.
Abetted by Wolski's swooping, receding camera and Jonathan Tunick's propulsive orchestrations, Burton makes this as fluid and dynamic as any screen ride this year, musical or otherwise.
Burton brings Sondheim's 1979 musical to the screen with a visual style informed by a truly cinematic feel for Grand Guignol.

Two hours of singing is going to bore the pants off of gore-starved viewers, and the last-reel gore is going to scare the pants of the foofy Broadway types. And that means a theatre full of people without pants.
Well-crafted if relatively impersonal.
What a pleasure it is, then, to report that Burton's version tends more to the abattoir than the amusement park...
It's testament to both the gonzo power of the source material and the completeness of Burton's vision that the movie works in spite of one teensy catch: they can't sing.
It is rare for a film to achieve a feeling of unequivocal, breathtaking transcendence, but Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street does just that.
Director Tim Burton has found the right look and, more crucially, the right scale for his film version of the grandiose 1979 Broadway musical thriller.
This killer Sweeney is thrillingly executed from start to splatter-ific finish.
Sure to make you nervous to get a haircut.

Singers that can't sing, repetitive tunes that aren't the least bit memorable and a director more in love with his macabre settings than with the story or the songs sure make for one long night at the movies.

Working with Johnny Depp, his favorite leading man, and Helena Bonham-Carter, his off- and on-screen muse, Burton creates a vast world of Victorian gothic menace that ideally sets off Stephen Sondheim's grimly intricate lyrics.
Here comes a Christmas musical that is not trying to warm the heart as much as rip it out while it's still beating. Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street is bloody perfect.
for all its unmistakable faults, it casts such a complete spell that I'm chomping at the bit to see it again
Those with strong stomachs will find this darkly comic piece is not just a bloody mess. Instead, it's bloody good fun.
Sweeney Todd is as much a horror film as a musical. It is also something close to a masterpiece.

Burton brings his signature visual style, and a pair of stock players for his stars, into this film adaptation, but he wisely follows Sondheim's lead, letting the music and spirit of the original piece show the way.
Tim Burton's scaled-down adaptation chooses style over substance. The result, however, is still a pretty enjoyable film.
Sweeney Todd is the creative peak of an eccentric career and one of the year's very best films.
Burton has made some great pictures--Sweeney Todd is the culmination of them.
The sub-par singing detracts from the film, as it must. Then again, the whole point is that Tim Burton is smart enough not to make Sweeney Todd about the songs.
A fantastically haunting tale, a nightmare musical ... that's gripping from the first minor chord on the organ to the bloody, inevitable resolution.
Sweeney Todd is often considered Stephen Sondheim's masterpiece; it's too early to say, but it may be Tim Burton's as well.
Either audiences will lap up the exaggerated Grand Guignol theatrics with a nervous smile or they'll cower in their seats hoping to switch their tickets to the next available showing of Enchanted.
I'm not sure Tim Burton's Sweeney Todd works very well as a musical, but it's one hell of a movie.
The material, a Gothic yarn of bloody revenge, seems specially suited for the macabre hand of Tim Burton, but alas, such is not the case.
A consistently great experience, and I'd love to go back and see it again in three weeks when the Hot Topic generation has latched on to it and will be singing along in the theater.
Delightfully gruesome, it is laced with morbid humor, and yet a sense of tragedy and loss weighs heavily upon it.
It's as if Stephen Sondheim's musical was meant to be a Tim Burton movie all along.
Sweeney Todd is exactly the musical Burton fans have wished him to make. It's a bloody mess of vengeance and lost love, full of throat-slitting mayhem.
Burton's work here is strong and self-assured and never allows the lavish production design to dominate the storytelling.
[It] works as a big screen version of one of the great achievements of the musical stage, as a dark and scary horror film, and as Tim Burton's finest film in over a decade.

... easy to recommend. It's an intelligent adaptation of a brilliant piece of material, preserving most of what was good first time around and bringing to the fore all the additional aspects that film provides.
the perfect movie this holiday for anyone sick of jingle bells and angels getting their wings.
It pulls you into Burton's world with its stunning performances and visuals.
[Sweeney Todd] is a wonder to behold, but only those with Burton's acquired tastes would want to sample a pie overstuffed with such joylessness.
As the perfect marriage of maker and material, this dark, disturbing splatter-etta stands as the best film of 2007.
There's no hole in the floor for an orchestra pit,there's a lot of CGI and some razor-keen wit.If you don't know the show, just roll with it
Pairing his Burton's whimsy with Stephen Sondheim's witty lyrics and lilting melodies makes for a combination as engrossing as it is unlikely.
Very charming in its dark and twisted way, although not without some flaws and odd choices.
Touches on Dostoevskian notions of playing God and purging the world of its lowlife rabble, and at times Todd seems something of a proletariat hero, exacting class reparations by night and knife.
Poor Depp isn't up to the challenge of a musical. He may look menacing with his ivory skin and flashing eyes, but he sings like he's three drinks into a night at the local karaoke bar.
A warped dream of domestic bliss that leaves you horrified and inconsolable.
A conceptual masterstroke. Sweeney always wanted to be a revenger's tragedy to make us recoil in fright. Now it is. Merry Christmas.

This isn't a movie for lovers of Sondheim's grimly funny musical, as most of the jokes fall flat in this joyless version. It's a movie for people who'd like to hear Depp do another British accent and wear a Bride of Frankenstein wig.

It combines some of Tim Burton's favorite elements: The fantastic, the ghoulish, the bizarre, the unspeakable, the romantic and in Johnny Depp, he has an actor he has worked with since Edward Scissorhands and finds a perfect instrument.

An elegant horror film that takes pleasure in its own theatricality, gives pleasure with caustic wit, trusts the power of Stephen Sondheim's score and exults in flights of fancy that only a movie can provide.
Sweeney Todd left me torn. There were so many elements that I loved but then there were those constant, annoying songs.
There's something about the 1979 Stephen Sondheim musical that awakened something audacious and inspired in Burton, sparking him to make his best film since "Ed Wood."
The whole experience is underwhelming, except for the violence, which is entirely overwhelming.
No sentiment goes unbloodied in [Burton's] exuberantly dark Sweeney Todd.

The film benefits from Burton's consistency of vision. Swooping camera work and a sense of really discomfiting fantasy do the groundwork. When characters break into song, it fits in the world Burton has built.

Sondheim's original musical was already a mad synthesis of Jacobean shock, Brechtian irony and Dickensian pathos -- to which Burton's lush visuals add another layer of aesthetic distance. The overall effect is somewhere between melodrama and camp.
The most faithful and effective transfer of a musical to screen I've seen. And bloody good fun besides.
A great film, a landmark in musical cinema and the best movie of 2007.
The wait for a good Tim Burton movie is finally over.
Visually expansive and imaginative.
Depp may not be a trained singer, but his voice is more than passable, and his presence -- his Sweeney is Edward Scissorhands gone bad -- is perfect.
While certainly not for all viewers, and even if it takes a bit to gain viewer engagement and traction, the film turns out to be, pardon the obligatory pun, fairly bloody fun.
A symphony of blood, bravura, butchery, barbarity and beauty, this film could quite possibly be the musical event of the year.

Burton is one of the truest of originals in the business of big-budget filmmaking, with a baroque imagination, a fetishistic love of detail, a perverse sense of humor and the courage to see his inspirations through to their most outlandish extremes.
It's Sondheim's gorgeously dissonate score that makes the greatest impact. The lush strings and emphatic horns can't help but lift the spirit even as they chill the bones.
Stylized but spasmodic, this Sweeney seems more interested in distancing than captivating an audience.
Sometimes jaunty, often dark, and very stylized. In other words, it's a perfect fit for director Tim Burton.
Burton's overall restraint is a welcome surprise. Shorn of his usual camp trappings, the director evokes a sadness beneath every uneasy smile he draws from the audience.
I'm a tough audience for Sweeney Todd, since I've probably played the original cast album a thousand times, but even I think it's worth your time.
It's easily Burton's best since, well, ever.
Tim Burton's grand guignol fantasy transforms Stephen Sondheim's 1979 musical-theater piece into a cheerfully gothic morality tale.
Mesmerizing and highly entertaining.
Like a lot of Sondheim's plays, it's a mixed bag of pros and cons, but Sweeney Todd is worth seeing for Carter alone, much less the excellent design on every level.
The most elegant slasher movie ever made.

It has vision to spare, which is rare enough in the modern cinema, and it was made by a director clearly in love with his material, which is rarer. It is not the definitive version of the musical, but maybe we don't need a definitive version.
Personally, I have never sung a love song to my razor, although I did hoist a boom-box over my head and crank Peter Gabriel's In Your Eyes to my pomade once back in 1989.
It's like Dario Argento blood just spurting everywhere...
A movie musical for people who don't like musicals, in the way that -- for example -- Kenneth Branagh's 'Frankenstein' was a horror movie for people who don't like horror movies.
If there were a cinematic version of a harmonic convergence, it would look something like "Sweeney Todd."

This Sweeney Todd is all subtext and no substance. It starts off large and swaggering but doesn't know where to turn next: Burton seems fixated on serving up an event, to the extent that he neglects to dig into the story.
[W]e haven't seen this much hemoglobin in a Johnny Depp film since the infamous blood geyser in A Nightmare on Elm Street.
A wickedly entertaining blood feast.

[A]ll operatic gruesomeness and cobblestones-and-fog moodiness, [this] is perfect. One of the most perfect movies ever, maybe, and sure to be pointed to for forever as the way to do a movie musical right.
Unparalleled visual splendor, a bloody red-velvet fever dream of a musical for people who think they HATE musicals.

Admittedly it is bloody as hell, but there's something just stylish enough about the way it's executed -- pun intended -- that even viewers with weak constitutions should be able to stomach the violence.
The result is a musical that I dare say works even better on screen than on stage.
It's a delightfully bloody trip to a grimy, but melodic, Victorian London.
Tim Burton's most focused, alert and satisfying film since Ed Wood
Bloody good, a lusciously Grand Guignol excercise that's true to the composer's original vision but spectacularly cinematic as well.
This version glories in the gory. Depp's singing limitations rob the character of Sweeney of his all-important contagious savage fury.
It may not be Burton's best film, or his most innovative, but it always stays faithful to his uniquely haunted soul.
This black cauldron of a film, with its spider-blood visual scheme, may be the purest example of imagemaking the movies have given us in far too long.
Though the trailer for Once might pique your curiosity, you don't know the freight train of raw emotion that's about to blindside you.
... Burton and Depp put their stamp on Sweeney Todd, bringing the Demon Barber of Fleet Street to life for a whole new audience.
What the movie version of Sweeney Todd preserves best is the corrosive power of Todd's revenge and the intricate rhymes of Sondheim's lyrics.

There's thrilling, as in 'producing sudden, strong and deep emotion or excitement.' And there's thrilling %u2014 as in 'moving with rapture; delighting beyond measure.' Star Johnny Depp and director Tim Burton's sixth collaboration is both: a striking, so
Should have been a standing triple for Burton to hit off the wall instead of hitting it head-on until the guignol nature became less than grand.
Murder, music, and monsters happily drenched in blood.
...an epic told in incomplete lyric lines, a classic fable forged out of slowly strummed guitar, lilting piano, and strained, struggling voices.
The imagery, music, and intoxicating blend of vengeance and madness--with just a smidgen of Priest; you'll see, if you don't already know--will linger long after you leave the theater.

criticName: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
quote: Love the play, but this film adaptation left a bad taste in my mouth.
Great idea--a musical with actors who can't sing.
The brooding gothic romanticism of the source material plays right into Burton's cinematic wheelhouse.
If only Johnny Depp had made his Willy Wonka this disturbingly attractive.
From the movie's opening organ blast to the pieta with which it ends, 'Sweeney Todd' is a formally precise artwork about vice washing away virtue.
Johnny Depp's dynamic performance in the title role is Oscar worthy, and arguably the greatest of his career.
One word sums this up. Bravo!
Amy Adams provides the pixie dust that turns New York into a land of enchantment.

"The Wizard of Oz" celebrates its 75th anniversary looking younger and more vital than ever, simultaneously advertising good old-fashioned storytelling and the most advanced technology available.

Any reason to show your children "The Wizard of Oz" on a big screen seems like a good one.

A dubious proposition for the Francophobic, but it acquits itself with a script so ridiculous that it can't help but be engaging.
For all the tumultuous entrances and flouncing exits, the eight principals manage maybe three laughs among them.
Seduction is more important than deduction in this chic display of star quality to the eighth power.
The film weaves visual elegance, lesbian subtext, six hilariously inappropriate song-and-dance numbers and a flair for chiffon into a showcase for leading ladies of French cinema past and present.

Ten well-deserved Oscars -- plus a special award for Jerome Robbins's dynamic choreography -- adorned this electrifying and moving version of the magnificent Leonard Bernstein/Stephen Sondheim musical.

From the incredible performances to the outstanding songs to all of the technical marvels behind and in front of the camera, there isn't a single weak link to be found.

It took more than a quarter of a century to bring the 1975 musical Chicago to the screen, but it was worth the wait to get it right.
It's refreshing to see a robust, streamlined adaptation that drips with steamy sex appeal while staying true to the original.
With performers as good as these and the freshness of Bill Condon's screenplay and Marshall's direction, there's really very little wrong with Chicago. What it lacks is something intangible -- heat.
As sentimental as a plywood casket, Chicago has satirical bite and a mean wit that somehow never obscures its characters' unlikely likability.

Pure, delirious, irresistible joy.

an art film and an exploitation film, a comedy and a musical, a celebration of the Beatles and a satire of their fame and fortune

Enchanted is a sweet romantic fable, with some loveable performances and some genuine good humour.

Disney's enthralling, enormously entertaining film version of Stephen Sondheim's 1987 Broadway musical comedy is such a joy it makes you wonder what took them so long...Director Rob Marshall (Chicago) never puts a foot, or a note, wrong.
Sondheim's contrapuntal harmonies and intricate wordplay may not leave you humming but they are full of beauty and rueful wisdom.
The third act, in fact, is practically one long effects sequence (and those are never tiresome).
A disclaimer: Despite a dizzying and delightful first half, the film ultimately devolves into a very grim fairy tale.
The movie may not deliver every Sondheim fanatic's hopes for a perfect cinematic Into the Woods but it makes for at least a respectable, if not remarkable night at the movies.
Cry-Baby doesn`t have a subject, but only a format-a rickety framework erected to support a few broad gags and a few indifferently filmed production numbers.
Cry-Baby takes digs at Jailhouse Rock in a musical number that Elvis would have loved to do.
John Waters progressed from the truly disgusting ("Pink Flamingoes") to the truly funny ("Hair Spray") only to now hit the mainstream wall.
As Waters moves to a more conventional type of satire, he is losing some of the edge that gave his earlier films their crass appeal.
Waters's writing is woefully uneven. It's as if Sam Kinison had decided to tell knock-knock jokes -- sterile, unfunny knock-knock jokes at that.
The nostalgic delights in Waters's reform school drool are often more subtle than his other period offering, Hairspray, but it's still a polished debunking of pop culture from the "Pope of Trash".
Waters's feeling for the mid-50s doesn't really match his sense of the early 60s, and his plot moves seem increasingly formulaic.

I don't quite know how Waters did it (and I have absolutely no idea why he did it), but the fact that Cry-Baby is fun suggests that the filmmaker possesses an instinctive understanding of what made those Elvis pictures so successful in the first place.
It all adds up to zany, wide-eyed, quintessential Waters havoc -- the "kinder, gentler" 1990s brand, perhaps. But the genuine article, nonetheless.
The wizard of odd still runs amok.

If Cry-Baby has a message, it's that Cry-Baby and Allison deserve each other because they're young and they're beautiful, which certainly runs counter to Waters' affection for the grotesque, the bad and the ugly.
Cry-Baby is often sweet-spirited even when its crummy, but there's also something fetid in its foolery.
For a while the actors seem intimidated by the '50s references, but the film eventually develops a musical energy that carries the day.
The story never seems to end. It just keeps lurching on, anti-climax after anti-climax.
No amount of good acting, quality singing and clever songs can cover the fact that it feels like ... two movies stuck together.

This sprawling, blistering state-of-the-reunion-address is Spike Lee's most vital movie in years.
The film itself is frustratingly inconsistent and never finds a rhythm to carry it from scene to scene.

Frustrating and wildly uneven, "Chi-Raq" is also Lee's most interesting project in nearly a decade, since the slick thriller "Inside Man" and the excellent Hurricane Katrina documentary for HBO, "When the Levees Broke," both from 2006.
Even if the now-veteran director lays everything on a bit thick... he's still found a lively and legitimate way to tackle an urgent subject matter that other filmmakers have found excuses to avoid.
In "Chi-raq," Lee mixes fierce agitprop with lyrical musical numbers and Greek-inspired sex farce in hip hop verse. It's a mad combination that fittingly addresses a world of madness.

It's a shattering, thunderous wake-up alarm, a call to lay down arms, a gutsy social satire and a highly stylized work of fiction that sometimes feels as accurate and sobering as the crime reporting you see on the front page of this newspaper.

While formally quite different from [Lee's] more universally-respected early work, Chi-Raq has the exuberance and wit you'll find in Do The Right Thing and Crooklyn. It's the best film he's made in a very long time.
As 'Chi-Raq''s world expands, Lee's true target comes into focus: Chi-Raq is Chicago is America, and we are all, in our own way, responsible.
The best adaptation of a classic play into ghetto fabulous fare since the inspired reinterpretation of Romeo and Juliet as Romeo Must Die (2000).
Film benefits from great musical numbers and its portrait of the show's director, one of the few well-developed gay characters in a 1930's Hollywood film.
Spike Lee's state-of-the-union address has ambition to burn, and it burns it to the ground.
While its ambition does show a director still aspiring for great heights, its patchy execution only partly restores the faith.
A Spike Lee joint in the urgent sociopolitical register of Radio Raheem's boombox--a call to arms that's also a call to disarm.

Lee's finished project isn't strong enough to meet the mounting complaints against it -- or say anything meaningful about the city's murder rate that hasn't been said better elsewhere.

A powerful political call-to-arms (or call-away-from-arms) is dulled, but never entirely diminished, by an inconsistent third act.
Chi-Raq is a marvel. It's Lee resurrecting his voice - angry, impassioned and funny as hell - right when we need to hear it.
It is intense and uneven, moving and maddening, all in just about equal measure. But an angry Lee is an interesting Lee, and he's really angry here.
Lee knows when it's time to preach and when it's time to entertain.

Chi-Raq is rude and raunchy, consistently less amusing than it thinks it is, and thickly sliced with a very dull knife. Yet if not the breakthrough that Do the Right Thing was in '89 (though there are echoes), it's still fundamentally on-point.
What Aristophanes left to interpretation using ambiguity and metaphor, Lee beats down our throats, which sucks any fun right out of the film.
Chi-Raq, like so many Lee joints, is a jumble of ideas and approaches that clash and fall flat more often than they connect.
Those who dismiss Lee as a strident polemicist should take another look: "Chi-Raq" makes its points with a sharp wit and downright goofy humor.
[A]n important, engaging, heartbreaking, and enraging film -- but always entertaining, always visually striking, lyrically impressive, and filled with knockout performances.
Part sermon, part stand-up special and entirely, bizarrely entertaining.

There are many words and phrases to describe Chi-Raq. Preachy. Ambitious. Polarizing. Didactic. Maddening. Uneven. Strident. Surreal. Self-indulgent. Topical. Satirical. As subtle as a hammer to the head. But boring is not one of them.

It's a movie where a viewer would be hard-pressed to point out anything that really works; it's too gooey to bite as satire, and too much of a cartoon to be a sincere cri de coeur for the Second City's metastasized gang culture.
"Chi-Raq" doesn't always work, but it's a film that dares to take chances.
Along the way, the execution of the narrative gets muddled, but there's no denying that this risk-taking film has a pulse. A strong pulse.
Lee is propelled by righteous anger that can't help but be infectious. Even at his most reckless, even outlandish, he's on the side of the angels.

Lee doesn't pretend to possess the answers. But at least he's asking the hard questions, and putting them out there in a pop-culture form that engages us, moves us and motivates us to face facts and fear.
Chi-Raq hits often enough to keep Spike Lee current with the times.

Whether one likes the Marx Brothers or not, one has to admit that they could certainly entice a prima donna into accompanying them to the mad-house.
A Night At the Opera is quite the funniest, the most ambitious and the most entertaining of any of the Marx cinema offerings.
Groucho follows his own formula of throwing out gags, good and bad. as fast as he can talk, letting the good ones float the bad ones, trusting that the average will favor him.
This is pantomime at its best, and the greatest clown of the three is Harpo.
To attempt to criticize the Marxes is heresy and schism and we'll have none of it.

Clowning such as these players indulge in must be clever if it is not to become boring, and the fact that their idiosyncrasies, no matter how extravagant, never pall, is the best indication of the success they achieve.
A Night at the Opera is the most beautifully timed madness of 1935.
The scenes at the opera house during a performance offer not only good music but extremely laugh-provoking comedy, caused by the antics of the Marx Brothers.
Considering that the dialogue of A Night at the Opera was written by two such theatrical craftsmen as George Kaufman and Morris Rysklnd, it reaches a surprising nadir of inanity.
Groucho, Chico and Harpo continue to be collectively and individually three of the really first-rate comedians of today. Their only peers are Mr. Charles Chaplin and Mr. W. C. Fields.

Their eccentric adventures from Milan to New York contain such notable scenes as that in Groucho's cabin; the impersonation of the foreign aviators; the disruption of the opera orchestra; and the final, breathless sequences.

Uproarious high spots -- the best, perhaps, of their kind -- render A Night at the Opera, starring Groucho, Harpo and Chico, a champion comedy in the year's output. In some ways, it is the best comedy in which the three brothers have ever appeared.

A loving musical tribute, a raucous comedy and an amazing demolition derby -- The Blues brothers is all these and more. Filmed in and near Chicago, the home of electric blues, it is extravagant pandemonium -- continuous and delightful.
The plot here is merely an excuse to slam Big Names up on the Big Screen and enact enough big crashes to give some of us a big headache.

Between [musical] numbers there are a number of good laughs, but most of the comedy falls flat through constant over-statement. The 20-car prang where two might do philosophy, spills through the whole film.

It is Jolson's dynamic singing... recorded by the Vitaphone process on disc and synchronised to the action, that breathes life into a movie whose pioneering aspect is its main interest.

How far this interesting combination of sound and sight may yet be carried on the way to uttermost artistic perfection must remain a matter of speculation, but this need not for a single moment hold one back from enjoying The Jazz Singer as it stands.
Gripping, emotional, and intensely realistic, the story is almost a parallel in Jolson's own career.

The picture has been cannily directed. finely staged, and splendidly photographed. The vitaphone is cunningly utilized in some of the scenes and you HEAR the star sing some of his best loved songs.

Entertainment all the way through, the sort of box-office combination of tears and smiles that always will be sure-fire, The Jazz Singer is nothing short of a magnificent triumph for Warner Brothers, for the Vitaphone, [and] for Al Jolson.
As a picture it is negligible. The Vitaphone and Al Jolson put it over. With every effort, apparently, made to produce a great picture, the result Is, unfortunately, second rate.

Coupled with the acting of Jolson. and the wonders of the Vitaphone, in which the synchronization is so good as to suggest further interesting developments in the way of talk pictures, [the film] provides about all the enjoyment that could be hoped for.

The Wizard of Oz is an exciting tour de force that keeps the eye and ear constantly occupied, bothers the brain very little. It is hearty and unsubtle, generous and sometimes, in its high riot, intoxicating.

Young 'and old will appreciate The Wizard of Oz. I think, however, they would enjoy it more if the action had been speeded up a trifle. Nevertheless, it will be one of the season's talked about offerings and you should see it.

Judy Garland takes the farm-kid Dorothy as a natural, and adds three hit songs. Bert Lahr's Cowardly Lion has the gusty verve of a Bowery comedian. Dancer Ray Bolster invests the Scarecrow with a lunatic charm.
Despite its shortcomings, The Wizard of Oz is a spectacle to be seen -- a fantastic romp that will be a treat for the youngsters and a welcome diversion for their oldsters.
The world of yesterday's, and perhaps tomorrow's, dreams created decades ago in the imagination of Frank L. Baum comes to the screen as a triumph of the movie camera in the realm of fantasy.

Audiences will fall under the spell of The Wizard of Oz just as does Dorothy, the heroine of this story, when a Kansas tornado blows her into the wonderful land of Oz. Remarkable technical effects and beautiful photography create an air of sheer magic.

Of gossamer weave and rainbow tints is this technicolor excursion into the never-never land that has come to the [screen] -- unreal, scarcely even to be imagined, yet persuading somehow that reality can be left behind without regret.
One cannot say that this is a rival to Disney, but it is as near to fantasy as one can get with human actors... I am under the spell of Oz.

Hair succeeds at all levels -- as lowdown fun, as affecting drama, as exhilarating spectacle and as provocative social observation.
